How It Works

The method behind the analysis

The Problem

Most literary "analysis" online is just summary. SparkNotes tells you what happens. LitCharts lists themes and quotes. None of it explains how the text creates meaning.

That's the gap between reading a book and writing a good essay about it. You know what happens. You can't explain why it matters.

The Method

Every analysis follows three layers. Each builds on the last — the output of one becomes the input for the next.

1

What's the story doing?

Three questions that reveal the machinery of how narrative works. The narrator's access, the reader's journey, the emotional effect.

2

What meaning is created?

How the narrative choices combine to produce themes and effects. This is where "the author uses symbolism" becomes "the restricted narrator makes us feel trapped alongside the protagonist."

3

Your thesis

The components assembled into a usable claim. Not a template you fill in — an argument built from the analysis, ready for your essay.

The connection between technique and effect — what essays actually need

The System Behind It

These analyses are built on a computational framework for understanding narrative. Every text is classified across dozens of variables — narrator type, focalization, structure, rhetoric, devices — then synthesised into the three-layer format.

The same framework powers our teaching method: students learn to recognise these patterns themselves, then articulate them in their own essays. Measurable improvement, not vague advice.

Built on a computational narratology framework — the same methodology used in doctoral-level literary research.
